values.description:
The z component of Vector3 elements parsed from urdf always contains 3.80985e+180 (FLT_MAX) because of an illegal index in parser_urdf.cc:255.

Vector3 elements are used internally for the model origin when spawning URDF models. gzclient crashes with the following error message directly after the model is spawned:


```
gzclient: /build/buildd/ogre-1.7.4/OgreMain/include/OgreAxisAlignedBox.h:252: void Ogre::AxisAlignedBox::setExtents(const Ogre::Vector3&, const Ogre::Vector3&): Assertion `(min.x <= max.x && min.y <= max.y && min.z <= max.z) && "The minimum corner of the box must be less than or equal to maximum corner"' failed.
```
values.title: Fixed parsing of Vector3 from strings in URDF parser

summary.raw:
The z component of Vector3 elements parsed from urdf always contains 3.80985e+180 (FLT_MAX) because of an illegal index in parser_urdf.cc:255.

Vector3 elements are used internally for the model origin when spawning URDF models. gzclient crashes with the following error message directly after the model is spawned:


```
gzclient: /build/buildd/ogre-1.7.4/OgreMain/include/OgreAxisAlignedBox.h:252: void Ogre::AxisAlignedBox::setExtents(const Ogre::Vector3&, const Ogre::Vector3&): Assertion `(min.x <= max.x && min.y <= max.y && min.z <= max.z) && "The minimum corner of the box must be less than or equal to maximum corner"' failed.
```
summary.html:
The z component of Vector3 elements parsed from urdf always contains 3.80985e+180 (FLT_MAX) because of an illegal index in parser_urdf.cc:255.

Vector3 elements are used internally for the model origin when spawning URDF models. gzclient crashes with the following error message directly after the model is spawned:

gzclient: /build/buildd/ogre-1.7.4/OgreMain/include/OgreAxisAlignedBox.h:252: void Ogre::AxisAlignedBox::setExtents(const Ogre::Vector3&, const Ogre::Vector3&): Assertion `(min.x <= max.x && min.y <= max.y && min.z <= max.z) && "The minimum corner of the box must be less than or equal to maximum corner"' failed.

values.title: Merge from 1.4 to default

values.description:
Addresses issues #5 and #6.  To minimize required code changes, I renamed the top-level elements (e.g., `include/sdformat-X.Y` and `share/sdformat`), but not anything inside (e.g., `include/sdformat-X.Y/sdf`).

After this change is merged, users should get build flags for sdformat via:

    find_package(SDFormat)

or:

    pkg_check_modules(SDFormat sdformat)

This pull request leaves behind the old `SDFConfig.cmake` and `sdf.pc` files to allow current code to keep building for one release cycle.
values.title: Rename top-level files/directories from sdf to sdformat

summary.raw:
Addresses issues #5 and #6.  To minimize required code changes, I renamed the top-level elements (e.g., `include/sdformat-X.Y` and `share/sdformat`), but not anything inside (e.g., `include/sdformat-X.Y/sdf`).

After this change is merged, users should get build flags for sdformat via:

    find_package(SDFormat)

or:

    pkg_check_modules(SDFormat sdformat)

This pull request leaves behind the old `SDFConfig.cmake` and `sdf.pc` files to allow current code to keep building for one release cycle.
summary.html:
Addresses issues #5 and #6. To minimize required code changes, I renamed the top-level elements (e.g., include/sdformat-X.Y and share/sdformat), but not anything inside (e.g., include/sdformat-X.Y/sdf).

After this change is merged, users should get build flags for sdformat via:

find_package(SDFormat)

or:

pkg_check_modules(SDFormat sdformat)

This pull request leaves behind the old SDFConfig.cmake and sdf.pc files to allow current code to keep building for one release cycle.

values.description:
Fixes #11 by using 1e-3 as equality tolerance for `Vector3`, which is what's used [in Gazebo's math library](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/3db618e7baa3c8a6a1db5e34cd220d24404a7960/gazebo/math/Vector3.cc?at=default#cl-318).

There are other places in Gazebo's math library where non-default tolerances are used in comparisons, but this is the minimal fix required to make the current test suite pass.
values.title: restore old equality operator tolerance

summary.raw:
Fixes #11 by using 1e-3 as equality tolerance for `Vector3`, which is what's used [in Gazebo's math library](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/3db618e7baa3c8a6a1db5e34cd220d24404a7960/gazebo/math/Vector3.cc?at=default#cl-318).

There are other places in Gazebo's math library where non-default tolerances are used in comparisons, but this is the minimal fix required to make the current test suite pass.
summary.html:
Fixes #11 by using 1e-3 as equality tolerance for Vector3, which is what's used in Gazebo's math library.

There are other places in Gazebo's math library where non-default tolerances are used in comparisons, but this is the minimal fix required to make the current test suite pass.

values.description:
Simple changes to be able to create test with prefixes for different proposes, currently UNIT_ and PERFORMANCE_.

Once this is done, we can choose which category to run in jenkins and be able to use the performance plug-in in results coming from performance tests.
values.title: Support to categorize test with prefixes

summary.raw:
Simple changes to be able to create test with prefixes for different proposes, currently UNIT_ and PERFORMANCE_.

Once this is done, we can choose which category to run in jenkins and be able to use the performance plug-in in results coming from performance tests.
summary.html:
Simple changes to be able to create test with prefixes for different proposes, currently UNIT_ and PERFORMANCE_.

Once this is done, we can choose which category to run in jenkins and be able to use the performance plug-in in results coming from performance tests.

values.description:
Fixed SDF_TEST, which was seg-faulting when calling setenv.

Fixed compiler warnings:
~~~
clang: warning: argument unused during compilation: '-s'
~~~
~~~
sdformat/include/sdf/Types.hh:529:20: warning: declaration shadows a field of 'sdf::Quaternion'
      [-Wshadow]
      double r, p, y;
                   ^
sdformat/include/sdf/Types.hh:570:20: note: previous declaration is here
    public: double y;
                   ^
~~~

code_check: whitespace in Types.hh and unused variable in Console.hh

values.description:
Converted a couple of uses of bare pointer to shared pointers in the URDF parser, seeking to address memory leaks identified in issue #13.

With this change, tests pass, gazebo_1.9 and drcsim_2.7 build, and I can launch `atlas_sandia_hands.launch`.  So I don't think that I broke anything.

And `valgrind -v --leak-check=yes --leak-check=full --show-reachable=yes ./test/performance/parser_urdf` says:

~~~
==15511== LEAK SUMMARY:
==15511==    definitely lost: 0 bytes in 0 blocks
==15511==    indirectly lost: 0 bytes in 0 blocks
==15511==      possibly lost: 0 bytes in 0 blocks
==15511==    still reachable: 808 bytes in 1 blocks
==15511==         suppressed: 0 bytes in 0 blocks
~~~
values.title: Use shared pointers to fix memory leaks (#13)

summary.raw:
Converted a couple of uses of bare pointer to shared pointers in the URDF parser, seeking to address memory leaks identified in issue #13.

With this change, tests pass, gazebo_1.9 and drcsim_2.7 build, and I can launch `atlas_sandia_hands.launch`.  So I don't think that I broke anything.

And `valgrind -v --leak-check=yes --leak-check=full --show-reachable=yes ./test/performance/parser_urdf` says:

~~~
==15511== LEAK SUMMARY:
==15511==    definitely lost: 0 bytes in 0 blocks
==15511==    indirectly lost: 0 bytes in 0 blocks
==15511==      possibly lost: 0 bytes in 0 blocks
==15511==    still reachable: 808 bytes in 1 blocks
==15511==         suppressed: 0 bytes in 0 blocks
~~~
summary.html:
Converted a couple of uses of bare pointer to shared pointers in the URDF parser, seeking to address memory leaks identified in issue #13.

With this change, tests pass, gazebo_1.9 and drcsim_2.7 build, and I can launch atlas_sandia_hands.launch. So I don't think that I broke anything.

And valgrind -v --leak-check=yes --leak-check=full --show-reachable=yes ./test/performance/parser_urdf says:

==15511== LEAK SUMMARY:
==15511==    definitely lost: 0 bytes in 0 blocks
==15511==    indirectly lost: 0 bytes in 0 blocks
==15511==      possibly lost: 0 bytes in 0 blocks
==15511==    still reachable: 808 bytes in 1 blocks
==15511==         suppressed: 0 bytes in 0 blocks

values.title: merging some updates from simbody branch and update default friction values, remove max friction values.

values.description:
**UPDATE:** 2c12b9833336 keeps the color control characters out of the log file (but still sends them to the terminal).

Add an ostream-like class with a << operator that can print to a console and a
file. All messages go to ~/.sdformat/sdformat.log. Error, Warning, and Msg
messages additionally go to stderr.

Two inelegant aspects of this implementation:

1. The control characters that colorize the console output also go to the log
file, making it slightly less readable.
1. The Console::ConsoleStream class does not fully implement the ostream spec;
e.g., you can't pass std::endl to it.

With the new logging system in place, I made two changes to what is logged, at
what level:

1. On the assumption that they were commented out to avoid console spam,
I uncommented all the working sdfdbg invocations in parser_urdf.cc.
1. Demoted two common messages in parser_urdf.cc from sdfwarn to sdfdbg.

Once we're happy with a mechanism like this, we should consider back-porting it to [Gazebo](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issue/79).
values.title: Log messages to file (#8)

summary.raw:
**UPDATE:** 2c12b9833336 keeps the color control characters out of the log file (but still sends them to the terminal).

Add an ostream-like class with a << operator that can print to a console and a
file. All messages go to ~/.sdformat/sdformat.log. Error, Warning, and Msg
messages additionally go to stderr.

Two inelegant aspects of this implementation:

1. The control characters that colorize the console output also go to the log
file, making it slightly less readable.
1. The Console::ConsoleStream class does not fully implement the ostream spec;
e.g., you can't pass std::endl to it.

With the new logging system in place, I made two changes to what is logged, at
what level:

1. On the assumption that they were commented out to avoid console spam,
I uncommented all the working sdfdbg invocations in parser_urdf.cc.
1. Demoted two common messages in parser_urdf.cc from sdfwarn to sdfdbg.

Once we're happy with a mechanism like this, we should consider back-porting it to [Gazebo](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issue/79).
summary.html:
UPDATE: 2c12b9833336 keeps the color control characters out of the log file (but still sends them to the terminal).

Add an ostream-like class with a << operator that can print to a console and a file. All messages go to ~/.sdformat/sdformat.log. Error, Warning, and Msg messages additionally go to stderr.

Two inelegant aspects of this implementation:

  1. The control characters that colorize the console output also go to the log file, making it slightly less readable.
  2. The Console::ConsoleStream class does not fully implement the ostream spec; e.g., you can't pass std::endl to it.

With the new logging system in place, I made two changes to what is logged, at what level:

  1. On the assumption that they were commented out to avoid console spam, I uncommented all the working sdfdbg invocations in parser_urdf.cc.
  2. Demoted two common messages in parser_urdf.cc from sdfwarn to sdfdbg.

Once we're happy with a mechanism like this, we should consider back-porting it to Gazebo.

values.description:
This includes pull request #34, pull request #35, and pull request #37. I think these are all intended to go to sdf_1.4. @nkoenig can you confirm?

After this, we can merge sdf_1.4 back to default.

Then I would propose a release of sdformat.
values.title: Merge default into sdf_1.4

summary.raw:
This includes pull request #34, pull request #35, and pull request #37. I think these are all intended to go to sdf_1.4. @nkoenig can you confirm?

After this, we can merge sdf_1.4 back to default.

Then I would propose a release of sdformat.
summary.html:
This includes pull request #34, pull request #35, and pull request #37. I think these are all intended to go to sdf_1.4. @nkoenig can you confirm?

After this, we can merge sdf_1.4 back to default.

Then I would propose a release of sdformat.

values.description:
Potential fix for [gazebo issue #740](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issue/740/gzsdf-urdf-parser-ignores-properties-for).

@bit-pirate , can you try this out?

With this change and gazebo built from `gazebo_1.9`, `gzsdf print kobuki.urdf > test.sdf` gives me the following output, which looks promising:

~~~
    <link name='base_footprint'>
    [...]
      <collision name='base_footprint_collision_caster_back_link'>
        <pose>-0.135 0 0.0192 -1.5708 0 0</pose>
        <geometry>
          <cylinder>
            <length>0.0176</length>
            <radius>0.017</radius>
          </cylinder>
        </geometry>
        <surface>
          <contact>
            <ode>
              <kp>1e+08</kp>
              <kd>10000</kd>
            </ode>
          </contact>
          <friction>
            <ode>
              <mu>0</mu>
              <mu2>0</mu2>
            </ode>
          </friction>
        </surface>
      </collision>
      <collision name='base_footprint_collision_caster_front_link'>
        <pose>0.115 0 0.0172 -1.5708 0 0</pose>
        <geometry>
          <cylinder>
            <length>0.0176</length>
            <radius>0.017</radius>
          </cylinder>
        </geometry>
        <surface>
          <contact>
            <ode>
              <kp>1e+08</kp>
              <kd>10000</kd>
            </ode>
          </contact>
          <friction>
            <ode>
              <mu>0</mu>
              <mu2>0</mu2>
            </ode>
          </friction>
        </surface>
      </collision>
~~~

summary.html:
Potential fix for gazebo issue #740.

@bit-pirate , can you try this out?

With this change and gazebo built from gazebo_1.9, gzsdf print kobuki.urdf > test.sdf gives me the following output, which looks promising:

    <link name='base_footprint'>
    [...]
      <collision name='base_footprint_collision_caster_back_link'>
        <pose>-0.135 0 0.0192 -1.5708 0 0</pose>
        <geometry>
          <cylinder>
            <length>0.0176</length>
            <radius>0.017</radius>
          </cylinder>
        </geometry>
        <surface>
          <contact>
            <ode>
              <kp>1e+08</kp>
              <kd>10000</kd>
            </ode>
          </contact>
          <friction>
            <ode>
              <mu>0</mu>
              <mu2>0</mu2>
            </ode>
          </friction>
        </surface>
      </collision>
      <collision name='base_footprint_collision_caster_front_link'>
        <pose>0.115 0 0.0172 -1.5708 0 0</pose>
        <geometry>
          <cylinder>
            <length>0.0176</length>
            <radius>0.017</radius>
          </cylinder>
        </geometry>
        <surface>
          <contact>
            <ode>
              <kp>1e+08</kp>
              <kd>10000</kd>
            </ode>
          </contact>
          <friction>
            <ode>
              <mu>0</mu>
              <mu2>0</mu2>
            </ode>
          </friction>
        </surface>
      </collision>

values.description:
This includes some changes to the code_check script. I first noticed that cpplint wasn't checking source code files (it was checking header files). So I fixed that, and ended up massively cleaning up the script, since there was lots of duplicated code. We should do something similar for gazebo after this is reviewed.

I also fixed cpplint errors in `Console.cc`. I exclude the urdf parser and its test from cpplint, since they have collectively over 100 errors.
values.title: Code check fix and clean-up

summary.raw:
This includes some changes to the code_check script. I first noticed that cpplint wasn't checking source code files (it was checking header files). So I fixed that, and ended up massively cleaning up the script, since there was lots of duplicated code. We should do something similar for gazebo after this is reviewed.

I also fixed cpplint errors in `Console.cc`. I exclude the urdf parser and its test from cpplint, since they have collectively over 100 errors.
summary.html:
This includes some changes to the code_check script. I first noticed that cpplint wasn't checking source code files (it was checking header files). So I fixed that, and ended up massively cleaning up the script, since there was lots of duplicated code. We should do something similar for gazebo after this is reviewed.

I also fixed cpplint errors in Console.cc. I exclude the urdf parser and its test from cpplint, since they have collectively over 100 errors.

* All the elements are not required, except the gain and power.

values.description:
I get the following warning when spawning an urdf in drcsim:
~~~
Warning [parser.cc:356] No <sdf> element in file[data-string]
~~~

So I'm converting that warning to an sdflog.
values.title: Convert a few more sdfwarn's to sdflog, fix spelling error

values.description:
with test

Also removed comment on inertia rotation.  It's not the job of the parser to worry about how the data will be used, and this is also a non-issue now fixed by [gazebo pull request #379](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/379/handle-inertia-rotation-and-use-full-pose/diff).
values.title: fix for issue #22, reducing inertia across fixed joints

summary.raw:
with test

Also removed comment on inertia rotation.  It's not the job of the parser to worry about how the data will be used, and this is also a non-issue now fixed by [gazebo pull request #379](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/379/handle-inertia-rotation-and-use-full-pose/diff).
summary.html:
with test

Also removed comment on inertia rotation. It's not the job of the parser to worry about how the data will be used, and this is also a non-issue now fixed by gazebo pull request #379.
